 The idea of original sin, which is highly debated and complicated, is none the less central to Christian thought. Original sin is NOT a sin, strictly speaking, as I said earlier, because it does not involve a free choice. It is like a mark, if you will, of what happened to humanity and is explained mtaphorically in the tale of Adam and Eve. That mark consists in that, after that original, first sin, we have been imprinted with the tendency to sin. This does not mean that we have become innately evil. It means that the freedom of action that God gave us (originally to make each good act perfect) was tainted, and people began to freely make bad choices, as you say. This tendency of our will, this "opening of our eyes" to evil is what we know as original sin. That original sin is cleansed by the sacrament of baptism, without which, rigorously, we cannot be saved. Baptism, obviously, does not free us from the tendency to make those bad choices, but it does wash out that first bad choice for which Adam and Eve were cast from Heaven by God.

So, at very least, 92% of the time (37 weeks out of 40) when a woman of that day were forced to labor prematurely, the birth would be stillborn.  Because of this fact, I read a presumption in this passage from Exodus, that any "fruit" forced out of it's mother prior to term (especially caused by a violent) act would be assumed to be stillborn or die soon after birth.  Yes. 
 
 And FYI:
 Occassionally life is created that is genomically one sex but due to dysfunction (such as hormones not triggering in the body properly), that life fails to completely express it sexual identity during develpment. A person who is genomically XY, might be hormonally XX, or vice vera. Puberty is hard enough to go through without this added stress. Such people going through correctional operations, really deserve our support, not more humiliation. Imagine how much pain there would be involved in removing your genitals and replacing them with new ones? Openning up a vagina, where there wasn't one before? Amazing. People do not volunteer to go through these operations and subsequent drug therapies without serious reasons.
 
 Another more dramatic example of sexual ambiguity, is a condition called chimerism. It's very rare in humans, but occassionally during a pregnancy, if there are more than one zygote in the womb, such as is the case where there are twins, it's possible for the zygotes to become fused together during development. This results in a single person at birth with two distinct genomes. If one of those genomes is XX and the other XY, the result is one person who is biologically both male and female at the same time.
 
 So it's completely understandable that sex changes are needed.

To attempt a complete defintion of either using categories inherent to the knowledge of the other is an error of method. It is contradictory to the concept of soul to attempt to give it a localised, punctual "seat" in the body, because the soul, by definition, trascends the physicial (similar to the way God trascends the world). This does not mean that the body and the soul do not form, together, a unity, but that unity is a unity of physical and spiritual, meaning that the categories of the sciences of the physical world are inadequate for a complete understanding of the human person.

 Well, theology is a science, if we are working with a complete definition of Science. This is that science is the entirety and the methods of human knowledge. Thus, theology, law, economics. history or philosophy are also science. They are areas of human knowledge, each with their own methods of acquiring that knowledge. Then, we make a distinction between the empirical or physical sciences (those whose method is of experimentation and measuring), and the social or humanistic sciences, whose methods are different because they deal with unmeasurable factors (human freedom).

it goes to show that good and bad are relative. if a burglar is fleeing the scene of a crime and stumbles over the fence as he runs, and you, being the helpful neighbor stops to help him, making sure he's alright and that all the goods that fell out of the sack he was carrying is gathered up and given back to him, then sends him on his way, is that a good thing or a bad thing?

 
 Helping a burglar is, overall, a bad thing, because you are helping a wrongdoer further his purposes. However, in the face of ignorance, there can be no absolute freedom to act, becuase you don't know all the factors at hand. In this way, you act out of a desire to do good, but you in fact to bad (see, it's not relative: you objectively do bad, depsite what you think).

 The official doctrine of the Catholic Church has never turned away from its primary canons, never. The fact that evolution or gay rights are happening now and have never happened before doens't mean that we must revise Catholic doctrine, it means that we must test those theories and claims against our faith, and what we must determine is if and how they agree with it. In this way, the Catholic Church accepts evolution with some restraints (the restraints that derive from a constant doctrine of faith), and it does not accept gay rights because they go against that doctrine. There is no revising here.
